awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Human Communication in a Connected World
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site will offer an intellectually and socially stimulating research experience, on a vibrant and diverse set of research topics, focusing on digital communication. Increasing use of Internet in our daily lives requires research to support emerging trends in communication and information science, and education to prepare young people for rewarding careers in the decades to come.  Students involved in the program will receive extensive training in research, and valuable information about research careers, working with top faculty on exciting problems.  Each student will work with one mentor, but there will be many joint activities to create a cohort experience, and to support communication across parallel research projects, thereby enhancing scientific progress as well as student learning. This site is supported by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.

There are four themes, each led by one research mentor, under the common thrust of digital connectivity: (1) The communication theme focuses on hardware and infrastructure to support communication, tackling unsolved problems of limited bandwidth and constrained protocol design in novel ways, proposing optical routers, in-network computation and extensible protocol design.  (2) The cybersecurity theme focuses on securing communication from cyberattacks and damaging activities such as cyberbullying and cyberpredation, seeking solutions for several open problems, including safe malware analysis, large denial-of-service attacks, weak passwords, and the lack of privacy-safe sources of network data.  (3) The information retrieval theme focuses on mining useful information from online sources, to achieve natural-language understanding and generation, using powerful new constructs, such as Abstract Meaning Representation, universal language translation, and the structure of poetry.  (4) The information flow theme focuses on understanding structure and communication dynamics of social systems with a novel focus on cognitive factors and their impact on communication that has already uncovered phenomena that can change the way social networks present information to users, and the way people leverage crowdsourcing.

por.por_cntn:
This REU site at USC Information Sciences Instute (USC/ISI) ran for 3 years and recruited students from across the United States to perform research on networks, communications, scientific computing and social computing. Each year we advertised the program broadly and got between 50 to 300 applications. Each year 8-10 students were admitted into the program, seeking to balance the gender and race composition, and the ratio of students from top research institutions and those from institutions with limited opportunity for undergraduate research. Each year at least 50% of students were admitted from institutions with limited opportunity for undergraduate research.

Overall, 27 students were hosted in three years. Students worked with mentors at USC Information Sciences Institute (often one student to one mentor) on research projects. Students also attended professional development seminars at USC Information Sciences Institute. These seminars focused on three broad topics: graduate school preparation, learning important research skills and various research topics presented by mentors. Each year, students also participated in a local REU student symposium and presented their research (via a poster) to other REU programs in the area. They also presented their research to USC/ISI faculty, students and staff in the last week of the program.

In addition to professional development, each year we offered some social activities to build up cohort nature of the program. These included hikes to local places of interest, museum visits, a trip to the beach, etc. 

The program participants produced five publications over the program's duration, which are listed at https://reu.isi.edu/accomplishments.html (years 2018-2020).

Due to Covid-19 pandemic we had to offer the program virtually in 2020. This format was challenging for social interaction, but it worked reasonably well for research activities and professional development activities.

This first award funding our REU site has enabled us to learn what works well with students and what can be improved, and these findings informed our renewal effort (SURF-I, funded in 2021). We have implemented "research area meetings" where multiple students and mentors working on related research questions meet together. We have also increased frequency of student/mentor meetings and have clarified expectations of our program to students and mentors. We have further restructured the program to work more closely with students on publications, which can be submitted to special undergraduate student symposia. These changes have increased our publication output in the renewal effort and increased student and mentor engagement.
